elements.content: Functional crystalline materials based on bimetallic cyanido-bridged {[DyIII(4-Mephen)­(dmf)4]­[MV(CN)8]}·0.5H2O (M = Re, 1; Mo, 2; W, 3; 4-Mephen = 4-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline) helices have been prepared. 1 is the first heterometallic coordination polymer incorporating an unexplored [ReV(CN)8]3– ion. Implementation of the ReV-based diamagnetic analogue of broadly investigated paramagnetic [MoV(CN)8]3– and [WV(CN)8]3– ions into the d–f coordination framework results in yellow photoluminescence originating from 4F9/2 → 6H J f–f electronic transitions of DyIII sensitized by 4-Mephen, and field-induced slow magnetic relaxation related to the single-ion anisotropy of the dysprosium­(III) complexes. We prove that [ReV(CN)8]3– can work as a noninnocent metalloligand in the preparation of emissive 4f-metal-based single-molecule magnets.
elements.clean_text: Functional crystalline materials based on  bimetallic cyanido-bridged {[DyIII(4-Mephen)(dmf)4][MV(CN)8]}⋅0.5H2O (M = Re, 1; Mo, 2; W, 3; 4-Mephen = 4-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline) helices have been prepared. 1 is the first heterometallic coordination polymer incorporating an unexplored [ReV(CN)8]3- ion. Implementation of the ReV-based diamagnetic analogue of broadly investigated paramagnetic [MoV(CN)8]3- and [WV(CN)8]3- ions into the d-f coordination framework results in yellow photoluminescence originating from 4F9/2 → 6H J  f-f electronic transitions of DyIII sensitized by 4-Mephen, and field-induced slow magnetic relaxation related to the single-ion anisotropy of the dysprosium(III) complexes. We prove that [ReV(CN)8]3- can work as a noninnocent metalloligand in the preparation of emissive 4f-metal-based single-molecule magnets.

elements.content: Dysprosium­(III) complexes of 4-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline connected with octacyanidometallates of rhenium­(V), molybdenum­(V), and tungsten­(V) result in three novel heterometallic cyanido-bridged helices. The DyIIIReV derivative, the first coordination polymer incorporating [ReV(CN)8]3−, brings together DyIII-centered yellow photoluminescence and slow magnetic relaxation of anisotropic dysprosium­(III) complexes. We proved that diamagnetic and photostable [ReV(CN)8]3− is an exceptional candidate for creating of 4f-metal-based emissive single-molecule magnets, in comparison to its paramagnetic and light-sensitive [MoV(CN)8]3− and [WV(CN)8]3− analogues.
elements.clean_text: Dysprosium(III) complexes of 4-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline connected with octacyanidometallates of rhenium(V), molybdenum(V), and tungsten(V) result in three novel heterometallic cyanido-bridged helices. The DyIIIReV derivative, the first coordination polymer incorporating [ReV(CN)8]3-, brings together DyIII-centered yellow photoluminescence and slow magnetic relaxation of anisotropic dysprosium(III) complexes. We proved that diamagnetic and photostable [ReV(CN)8]3- is an exceptional candidate for creating of 4f-metal-based emissive single-molecule magnets, in comparison to its paramagnetic and light-sensitive [MoV(CN)8]3- and [WV(CN)8]3- analogues.

elements.content: Octacyanidometallates of molybdenum­(IV,V), tungsten­(IV,V), niobium­(IV), and rhenium­(V) have been at the forefront of research on heterometallic coordination networks for more than 2 decades. Similar to the [M­(CN)6]-based Prussian Blue analogues, octacyanido-bridged networks are a remarkable source of functional materials, revealing photomagnetism, optical activity, second harmonic generation (SHG), ionic conductivity, and porosity. They exhibit such magnetic properties as spin transitions, magnetic ordering, and slow magnetic relaxation. Their magnetism was combined with other physical functionalities, giving such cross effects such as magnetization-induced or photoswitchable SHG. Octacyanidometallates are also efficient molecular building blocks for magnetophotoluminescent materials. [MIV/V(CN)8]4–/3– ions are not emissive, but they do not absorb in the vis–near-IR (NIR) range. Thus, they allow one to observe emission from accompanying metal complexes, as shown in LnIII[M­(CN)8] n− coordination systems, exhibiting visible luminescence of EuIII and TbIII, or NIR emission of NdIII. Their optical effects could be combined with spin ordering, which resulted in luminescent magnets. On the contrary, [M­(CN)8] n− ions were not utilized in the synthesis of emissive single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which are the molecular objects showing slow relaxation of magnetization. SMMs are researched because of their application in information processing, related to the magnetic hysteresis loop of a molecular origin.
elements.clean_text: Octacyanidometallates of molybdenum(IV,V), tungsten(IV,V), niobium(IV), and rhenium(V) have been at the forefront of research on heterometallic coordination networks for more than 2 decades. Similar to the  [M(CN)6]-based Prussian Blue analogues, octacyanido-bridged networks are a remarkable source of functional  materials, revealing photomagnetism, optical activity, second harmonic generation (SHG), ionic conductivity, and porosity. They exhibit such magnetic properties as spin transitions, magnetic ordering, and slow magnetic relaxation. Their magnetism was combined with other physical functionalities, giving such cross effects such as magnetization-induced or photoswitchable SHG. Octacyanidometallates are also efficient molecular building blocks for magnetophotoluminescent materials. [MIV/V(CN)8]4-/3- ions are not emissive, but they do not absorb in the vis-near-IR (NIR) range. Thus, they allow one to observe emission from accompanying metal complexes, as shown in LnIII[M(CN)8] n- coordination systems, exhibiting visible luminescence of EuIII and TbIII, or NIR emission of NdIII. Their optical effects could be combined with spin ordering, which resulted in luminescent magnets. On the contrary, [M(CN)8] n- ions were not utilized in the synthesis of emissive single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which are the molecular objects showing slow relaxation of magnetization. SMMs are researched because of their application in information processing, related to the magnetic hysteresis loop of a molecular origin.

elements.content: A number of emissive SMMs, mainly based on mononuclear 4f metal ions, have been reported. We have found that photoluminescent SMMs can be created by lanthanide­(3+) ions inserted in coordination systems with hexacyanidometallates, [MIII(CN)6]3– (M = Co, Rh). Inspired by these results, we have undertaken a challenge to employ [M­(CN)8] n− ions for the construction of luminescent SMMs. Octacyanidometallates were used to induce SMM behavior in d-metal polynuclear clusters. In addition, some of the related d–f frameworks exhibited slow magnetic relaxation, but it was often quenched by magnetic coupling with [MoV/WV(CN)8]3–. Moreover, these cyanide complexes are not stable upon UV excitation because of photoreduction; thus, the luminescence from 4f metal ions is hampered. Therefore, we decided to focus our attention on the underexplored [ReV(CN)8]3– ion, which was only applied for the synthesis of cyanido-bridged polynuclear clusters. The [ReV(CN)8]3– metalloligand is a diamagnetic analogue of [WV(CN)8]3–, exhibiting better stability under UV-light irradiation. Therefore, [ReV(CN)8]3– is the prime candidate for d–f coordination frameworks combining UV-light-induced luminescence and slow magnetic relaxation. Following this line, we report cyanido-bridged {[DyIII(4-Mephen)­(dmf)4]­[ReV(CN)8]}·0.5H2O (1; 4-Mephen = 4-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline) chains showing yellow luminescence and slow magnetic relaxation. We also present MoV (2) and WV (3) analogues, which are emissive, but slow magnetic relaxation is quenched by magnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: A number of emissive SMMs, mainly based on mononuclear 4f metal ions, have been reported. We have found that photoluminescent SMMs can be created by lanthanide(3+) ions inserted in coordination systems with hexacyanidometallates, [MIII(CN)6]3- (M = Co, Rh). Inspired by these results, we have undertaken a challenge to employ [M(CN)8] n- ions for the construction of luminescent SMMs. Octacyanidometallates were used to induce SMM behavior in d-metal polynuclear clusters. In addition, some of the related d-f frameworks exhibited slow magnetic relaxation, but it was often quenched by magnetic coupling with [MoV/WV(CN)8]3-. Moreover, these cyanide complexes are not stable upon UV excitation because of photoreduction; thus, the luminescence from 4f metal ions is hampered. Therefore, we decided to focus our attention on the underexplored [ReV(CN)8]3- ion, which was only applied for the synthesis of cyanido-bridged polynuclear clusters. The [ReV(CN)8]3- metalloligand is a diamagnetic analogue of [WV(CN)8]3-, exhibiting better stability under UV-light irradiation. Therefore, [ReV(CN)8]3- is the prime candidate for d-f coordination frameworks combining UV-light-induced luminescence and slow magnetic relaxation. Following this line, we report cyanido-bridged {[DyIII(4-Mephen)(dmf)4][ReV(CN)8]}⋅0.5H2O (1; 4-Mephen = 4-methyl-1,10-phenanthroline) chains showing yellow luminescence and slow magnetic relaxation. We also present MoV (2) and WV (3) analogues, which are emissive, but slow magnetic relaxation is quenched by magnetic coupling.

elements.content: Compounds 1–3 were obtained as colorless (1 and 3) or yellow (2) needle crystals by the slow diffusion of diethyl ether into solutions of 4-Mephen, dysprosium­(III) nitrate, and organic salt of the respective octacyanidometallate in a mixed solvent of acetonitrile/methanol/N,N′-dimethylformamide (dmf; details are given in the Supporting Information). IR spectra measured for single crystals of 1–3 indicated the presence of organic ligand and bridging cyanides (Figure S1); thus, crystalline objects were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD; and Tables S1–S3 and Figures S2–S4). 1 is composed of helical cyanido-bridged chains composed of alternately arranged [Dy­(4-Mephen)­(dmf)4(μ-NC)2]− and [Re­(CN)8]3– moieties (a). Both dysprosium and rhenium complexes are eight-coordinated with the geometry of a square antiprism (Table S3). Because of 4-Mephen, the chains of 1 are not linear but display helicity (). These helices are determined by the tetrangular alignment of the Dy and Re centers (b). This results in the left- and right-handed helices depending on the connection of metal centers by cyanides. The crystal structure of 1 contains identical amounts of both types of helices, the arrangement of which is controlled by π–π interactions between the 4-Mephen ligands. The chains of 1 are aligned in parallel along the b axis, and their positions are stabilized by the above-mentioned π–π stacking and steric effect on the dmf ligands (Figure S3). The validity of the structural model for bulk samples was proven by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; Figure S5). Both SC-XRD and PXRD analyses were performed for 2 and 3 (Tables S1–S3 and Figures S2–S5), and they indicate the isostructurality of the DyMo (2) and DyW (3) analogues with DyRe (1).
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1-3 were obtained as colorless (1 and 3) or yellow (2) needle crystals by the slow diffusion of diethyl ether into solutions of 4-Mephen, dysprosium(III) nitrate, and organic salt of the respective octacyanidometallate in a mixed solvent of acetonitrile/methanol/N,N'-dimethylformamide (dmf; details are given in the Supporting Information). IR spectra measured for single crystals of 1-3 indicated the presence of organic ligand and bridging cyanides (Figure S1); thus, crystalline objects were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD;  and Tables S1-S3 and Figures S2-S4). 1 is composed of helical cyanido-bridged chains composed of alternately arranged [Dy(4-Mephen)(dmf)4(μ-NC)2]- and [Re(CN)8]3- moieties (a). Both dysprosium and rhenium complexes are eight-coordinated with the geometry of a square antiprism (Table S3). Because of 4-Mephen, the chains of 1 are not linear but display helicity (). These helices are determined by the tetrangular alignment of the Dy and Re centers (b). This results in the left- and right-handed helices depending on the connection of metal centers by cyanides. The crystal structure of 1 contains identical amounts of both types of helices, the arrangement of which is controlled by π-π interactions between the 4-Mephen ligands. The chains of 1 are aligned in parallel along the b axis, and their positions are stabilized by the above-mentioned π-π stacking and steric effect on the dmf ligands (Figure S3). The validity of the structural model for bulk samples was proven by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; Figure S5). Both SC-XRD and PXRD analyses were performed for 2 and 3 (Tables S1-S3 and Figures S2-S5), and they indicate the isostructurality of the DyMo (2) and DyW (3) analogues with DyRe (1).

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1: representative fragment of two co-coexisting chains of opposite helicities (a), and the helical arrangement of the metal centers shown in the ac plane (b).
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1: representative fragment of two co-coexisting chains of opposite helicities (a), and the helical arrangement of the metal centers shown in the ac plane (b).

elements.content: The optical properties of 1–3 are shown in and S6 and S7. 1 exhibits strong UV absorption related to the π–π*electronic transitions of 4-Mephen and combined contributions of the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) and d–d transitions of [ReV(CN)8]3– ions. There is only a weak absorption tail in the visible range up to ca. 500 nm, which can be ascribed to d–d transitions in [ReV(CN)8]3– (a). 2 and 3 exhibit similar absorption properties; however, a shift of the UV bands toward the visible region, in the sequence Re < W < Mo, is observed. It is assignable to the relatively low energy of the LMCT states of [Mo­(CN)8]3–, resulting in the yellow color of 2 (Figure S6). Under UV-light excitation, 1 exhibits a yellow emission consisting of two strong peaks at 485 and 575 nm and two weaker peaks at 662 and 749 nm (b). They are related to a series of f–f electronic transitions from the emissive 4F9/2 state of DyIII to the 6H15/2,13/2,11/2,9/2 and 6F11/2 levels. The excitation spectrum is dominated by a broad band at 270 nm, with other maxima at 297 and 325 nm. It could be assigned to the 4-Mephen ligand because identical excitation spectra were found in 2 and 3, also showing DyIII emission (Figure S7). This proves that photoluminescence of 1–3 is realized by energy transfer from 4-Mephen to DyIII. This interpretation is supported by the disappearance of ligand emission (Figure S7). 1–3 showed similar optical properties; however, the emission of 2 and 3 decreased during repeated measurements, while the emission of 1 remained constant under UV irradiation, suggesting much better photostability.

There is only a weak absorption tail in the visible range up to ca. 500 nm, which can be ascribed to d-d transitions in [ReV(CN)8]3- (a). 2 and 3 exhibit similar absorption properties; however, a  shift of the UV bands toward the visible region, in the sequence Re < W < Mo, is observed. It is assignable to the relatively low energy of the LMCT states of [Mo(CN)8]3-, resulting in the yellow color of 2 (Figure S6). Under UV-light excitation, 1 exhibits a yellow emission consisting of two strong peaks  at 485 and 575 nm and two weaker peaks at 662 and 749 nm (b). They are related to a series of f-f electronic transitions from the emissive 4F9/2 state of DyIII to the 6H15/2,13/2,11/2,9/2 and 6F11/2 levels. The excitation spectrum is dominated by a broad band  at 270 nm, with other maxima at 297 and 325 nm. It could be assigned to the 4-Mephen ligand because identical excitation spectra were found in 2 and 3, also showing DyIII emission (Figure S7). This proves that photoluminescence of 1-3 is realized by energy transfer from 4-Mephen to DyIII. This interpretation is supported by the disappearance of ligand emission (Figure S7). 1-3 showed similar optical properties; however, the emission of 2 and 3  decreased during repeated measurements, while the emission of 1 remained constant under  UV irradiation, suggesting much better photostability.

elements.content: Optical properties of 1: UV–vis–NIR absorption spectrum compared with the spectra of 4-Mephen and TBA3[Re­(CN)8] (a); emission spectrum for λexc = 297 nm with the indicated DyIII transitions and related excitation spectrum for λem = 575 nm (b). Absorption spectra were gathered at 298 K and emission spectra at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: 2  Optical properties of 1: UV-vis-NIR absorption spectrum compared with the spectra of 4-Mephen and TBA3[Re(CN)8] (a); emission spectrum for λexc = 297 nm with the indicated DyIII transitions and related excitation spectrum for λem = 575 nm (b). Absorption spectra were gathered at 298 K and emission spectra at 77 K.

elements.content: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1–3 are presented in a and S8. The room temperature χM T value of 1 is 14.2 cm3 mol–1 K–1, very close to 14.1 cm3 mol–1 K–1 expected for a free Dy3+ ion with the 6H15/2 ground-state multiplet. The analogous χM T values for 2 and 3 are 14.5 and 14.7 cm3 mol–1 K–1, respectively, which agree well with 14.5 cm3 mol–1 K–1 originating from the combined contributions of a noninteracting pair of Dy3+ and [MV(CN)8]3– (M = Mo, W) ions with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0. Upon cooling, χM T gradually decreases similarly in 1–3; thus, it can be ascribed to the crystal-field effect of the 6H15/2 multiplet, related to a thermal depopulation of its m J sublevels (a). However, below 50 K, χM T for 2 and 3 decrease faster than those for 1, reaching a deeper minimum of 8.6 cm3 mol–1 K–1 at 7 K, followed by a rapid increase of the signal below 5 K. In 1, χM T monotonically decreases in the whole T range. This indicates that 2 and 3 show antiferromagnetic coupling within M–CN–Dy linkages, leading to a ferrimagnetic spin chain, while the DyIII complexes in 1 are magnetically separated. Magnetization at 1.8 K for 1 reaches 5.0 μB at 50 kOe, which suggests that the ground-state doublet can be close to a m J = ±15/2 state. Magnetization curves at 1.8 K for 2 and 3 grow faster than that for 1, which is in line with the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling. The M(H) plots first reach lower values than those in 1 because of the ferrimagnetic character and later increase to 5.3 μB (2) and 5.2 μB (3) at 50 kOe, because of a field-induced spin inversion.
elements.clean_text: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1-3 are presented in a and S8. The room temperature χM T value of 1 is 14.2 cm3 mol-1 K-1, very close to 14.1 cm3 mol-1 K-1 expected for a free Dy3+ ion with the 6H15/2 ground-state multiplet. The analogous χM T values for 2 and 3 are 14.5 and 14.7 cm3 mol-1 K-1, respectively, which agree well with 14.5 cm3 mol-1 K-1 originating from the combined contributions of a noninteracting pair of Dy3+ and [MV(CN)8]3- (M = Mo, W) ions with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0. Upon cooling, χM T gradually decreases similarly in 1-3; thus, it can be ascribed to the crystal-field effect of the 6H15/2 multiplet, related to a thermal depopulation of its m  J  sublevels (a). However, below 50 K,  χM T  for 2 and 3 decrease faster than those for 1, reaching a deeper minimum of 8.6 cm3 mol-1 K-1 at 7 K, followed by a rapid increase of the signal below 5 K. In 1, χM T monotonically decreases in the whole T range. This indicates that 2 and 3 show antiferromagnetic coupling within M-CN-Dy linkages, leading to a ferrimagnetic spin chain, while the DyIII complexes in 1 are magnetically separated. Magnetization at 1.8 K for 1 reaches 5.0 μB at 50 kOe, which suggests that the ground-state doublet can be close to a  m  J  = ±15/2 state. Magnetization curves at 1.8 K for 2 and 3 grow faster than that for 1, which is in line with the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling. The M(H) plots first reach lower values than those in 1 because of the ferrimagnetic character and later increase  to 5.3 μB (2) and 5.2 μB (3) at 50 kOe, because of a field-induced spin inversion.

elements.content: Magnetic properties of 1–3: temperature dependences of χM T for 1–3 at H dc = 1500 Oe (a) with enlargement of the low T range (inset); frequency dependences of the out-of-phase ac susceptibility at various temperatures for 1 at H dc = 1500 Oe and H ac = 3 Oe (b); related T dependence of the relaxation times (c). The colored solid curves in part b are fittings according to the Debye model, while the colored solid lines in part c show the fittings for the range of 3.4–8 K, taking into account indicated relaxation processes.
elements.clean_text: 3  Magnetic properties of 1-3: temperature dependences of χM T for 1-3 at H dc = 1500 Oe (a) with enlargement of the low T range (inset); frequency dependences of the out-of-phase ac susceptibility at various temperatures for 1 at H dc = 1500 Oe and H ac = 3 Oe (b); related T dependence of the relaxation times (c). The colored solid curves in part b are fittings according to the Debye model, while the colored solid lines in part c show the fittings for the range of 3.4-8 K, taking into account indicated relaxation processes.

elements.content: Thanks to the presence of DyIII complexes in magnetic isolation, 1 exhibits slow magnetic relaxation, as shown in alternating-current (ac) magnetic studies ( and S9 and S10) At zero dc field, there is only a high-frequency tail of the out-of-phase susceptibility, χM′′, even at 1.8 K, but the distinct signal appears after a dc field is applied (Figure S9). An optimal dc field of 1500 Oe clearly induces a relaxation process, as depicted by the frequency-dependent χM′(T) and χM′′(T) curves below 8 K (). These plots, along with the related Argand χM′′(χM′) plots for the 1.8–6 K range, were analyzed using a Debye model (Figure S10). A single relaxation model was used, omitting the low-frequency range where the slower relaxation appears. The temperature dependence of the relaxation times, τ (c), was analyzed by taking into account multiple relaxation pathways, formulated using . τ − 1 = τ 0 − 1 ⁡ exp ( − U eff / k B T ) + B Raman T 9 + τ QTM − 1
elements.clean_text: Thanks to the presence of DyIII complexes in magnetic isolation, 1 exhibits slow magnetic relaxation, as shown in alternating-current (ac) magnetic studies ( and S9 and S10) At zero dc field, there is only a high-frequency tail of the out-of-phase susceptibility, χM'', even at 1.8 K, but the distinct signal appears after a dc field is applied (Figure S9). An optimal dc field of 1500 Oe clearly induces a relaxation process, as depicted by the frequency-dependent χM'(T) and χM''(T) curves below 8 K (). These plots, along with the related Argand χM''(χM') plots for the 1.8-6 K range, were analyzed using a Debye model (Figure S10). A single relaxation model was used, omitting the low-frequency range where the slower relaxation appears. The temperature dependence of the relaxation times, τ (c), was analyzed by taking into account multiple relaxation pathways, formulated using . 1       τ   - 1   =    τ   0    - 1   ⁡ exp  ( -   U   eff   /   k   B   T )  +   B   Raman     T   9   +    τ   QTM    - 1

elements.content: The three terms refer to the thermal Orbach relaxation, Raman process, and quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), respectively. To avoid overparametrization, we used these relaxation processes with four fitting parameters (U eff, τ0, B Raman, and τQTM), excluding the possible process of direct relaxation, which is expected to be weak for the low dc magnetic field. The best-fit parameters are U eff/k B = 16(1) K, τ0 = 3.5(9) × 10–5 s, B Raman = 7(2) × 10–6 s–1 K–9, and τQTM = 0.0049(8) s. The resulting parameters of Orbach relaxation are characteristic of SMMs; however, the energy barrier is moderate, presumably because of the poor axiality of the DyIII units in 1. The Orbach process seems to dominate at higher temperatures, while the QTM effect governs the relaxation at the very low temperatures, the reason for the lack of zero-dc-field SMM behavior (c). In addition, the nonnegligible contribution of the Raman process indicates the vital role of molecular vibrations, including the impact of spin–phonon coupling, recently discussed in the literature. 2 and 3, even under an applied dc field, show the onset of magnetic relaxation at only high frequencies (Figure S11), proving that paramagnetic MoV or WV hamper the SMM effect.
elements.clean_text: The three terms refer to the thermal Orbach relaxation, Raman process, and quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), respectively. To avoid overparametrization, we used these relaxation processes with four fitting parameters (U eff, τ0, B Raman, and τQTM), excluding the possible process of direct relaxation, which is expected to be weak for the  low dc magnetic field. The best-fit parameters are U eff/k B = 16(1) K, τ0 = 3.5(9) × 10-5 s, B Raman = 7(2) × 10-6 s-1 K-9, and τQTM = 0.0049(8) s. The resulting parameters of Orbach relaxation are characteristic of SMMs; however, the energy barrier is  moderate, presumably because of the  poor axiality of the DyIII units in 1. The Orbach process seems to dominate at higher temperatures, while the QTM effect governs the relaxation at the very low temperatures, the reason for the lack of zero-dc-field SMM behavior (c). In addition, the nonnegligible contribution of the Raman process indicates the vital role of molecular vibrations, including the  impact of spin-phonon coupling, recently discussed in the literature. 2 and 3, even under an applied dc field, show the onset of magnetic relaxation at only high frequencies (Figure S11), proving that paramagnetic MoV or WV hamper the SMM effect.

elements.content: In summary, we report DyIIIReV helices combining single-molecule magnetism and visible photoluminescence. Achieving the first coordination polymer involving [ReV(CN)8]3–, we were able to create anisotropic dysprosium­(III) complexes serving as emissive SMMs. We also present analogous helical chains with paramagnetic [MoV(CN)8]3– and [WV(CN)8]3–, which show visible emission but their slow magnetic relaxation is turned off because of CN–-mediated magnetic coupling. This proves that the [ReV(CN)8]3– is an excellent linker for functional materials, linking luminescence and quantum molecular magnetism. We are now exploring the helicity of the obtained chains toward enantiopure helices for the conjunction of chirality, emission, and SMM behavior.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report DyIIIReV helices combining single-molecule magnetism and  visible photoluminescence. Achieving the first coordination polymer involving [ReV(CN)8]3-, we were able to create  anisotropic dysprosium(III) complexes serving as emissive SMMs. We also present analogous helical chains with paramagnetic [MoV(CN)8]3- and [WV(CN)8]3-, which show visible emission but their slow magnetic relaxation  is turned off because of CN--mediated magnetic coupling. This proves that the [ReV(CN)8]3-  is an excellent  linker for functional  materials, linking luminescence and quantum molecular magnetism. We are now exploring the helicity of the obtained chains toward enantiopure helices for the conjunction of chirality, emission, and SMM behavior.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1: representative fragment of two co-coexisting chains of opposite helicities (a), and the helical arrangement of the metal centers shown in the ac plane (b).

cln_elements.content: Optical properties of 1: UV–vis–NIR absorption spectrum compared with the spectra of 4-Mephen and TBA3[Re­(CN)8] (a); emission spectrum for λexc = 297 nm with the indicated DyIII transitions and related excitation spectrum for λem = 575 nm (b). Absorption spectra were gathered at 298 K and emission spectra at 77 K.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Optical properties of 1: UV-vis-NIR absorption spectrum compared with the spectra of 4-Mephen and TBA3[Re(CN)8] (a); emission spectrum for λexc = 297 nm with the indicated DyIII transitions and related excitation spectrum for λem = 575 nm (b). Absorption spectra were gathered at 298 K and emission spectra at 77 K.

cln_elements.content: Magnetic properties of 1–3: temperature dependences of χM T for 1–3 at H dc = 1500 Oe (a) with enlargement of the low T range (inset); frequency dependences of the out-of-phase ac susceptibility at various temperatures for 1 at H dc = 1500 Oe and H ac = 3 Oe (b); related T dependence of the relaxation times (c). The colored solid curves in part b are fittings according to the Debye model, while the colored solid lines in part c show the fittings for the range of 3.4–8 K, taking into account indicated relaxation processes.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Magnetic properties of 1-3: temperature dependences of χM T for 1-3 at H dc = 1500 Oe (a) with enlargement of the low T range (inset); frequency dependences of the out-of-phase ac susceptibility at various temperatures for 1 at H dc = 1500 Oe and H ac = 3 Oe (b); related T dependence of the relaxation times (c). The colored solid curves in part b are fittings according to the Debye model, while the colored solid lines in part c show the fittings for the range of 3.4-8 K, taking into account indicated relaxation processes.

metadata.title:
Connecting Visible Photoluminescence
and Slow Magnetic Relaxation
in Dysprosium(III) Octacyanidorhenate(V)  Helices
